answers.text: Federalism refers to the mixed or compound mode of government

qas.question: In Federalism, are the division of powers equal?

answers.text: division of powers between two levels of government of equal status

qas.question: What type of governments are included in federalism?

answers.text: general government (the central or 'federal' government) with regional governments

qas.question: How many governments are apart of federalism?

answers.text: relationship of parity between the two levels of government

plausible_answers.text: mode of government, combining a general government (the central or 'federal' government) with regional governments
a relationship of parity between the two levels of government established

qas.question: What features are indistinctive of federalism?
What document rejected modern federalist government?

plausible_answers.text: a relationship of parity between the two levels of government established

qas.question: What distinguishes Federalism from no other types of government?

plausible_answers.text: general government (the central or 'federal' government) with regional governments

qas.question: Federalism combines what three types of government?

context: <a0_0>Federalism refers to the mixed or compound <b4_0>mode of government<a0_0/>, combining a <a2_0><b8_0>general government (the central or 'federal' government) with regional governments<b8_0/><b4_0/><a2_0/> (provincial, state, Land, cantonal, territorial or other sub-unit governments) in a single political system. Its distinctive feature, exemplified in the founding example of modern federalism of the United States of America under the <b6_0>Constitution of 1789<b6_0/>, is <b5_0><b7_0>a <a3_0>relationship of parity between the two levels of government<a3_0/> established<b7_0/><b5_0/>. It can thus be defined as a form of government in which there is a <a1_0>division of powers between two levels of government of equal status<a1_0/>.
